It doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re cold, reserved, awkward, or even â€œquiet.â€ I am often mistaken for an extrovert because Iâ€™m very warm and friendly; but I can only take a little bit of big-group socializing before I get exhausted and have to recharge.

Right, you donâ€™t *have* to follow influencers or fitness gurus. You can follow like... your friends, people who inspire you in a positive way, funny meme accounts, cute animals, etc. Itâ€™s not a requirement of using social media to follow influencers. 

Itâ€™s all about empowering yourself to curate the online experience you want to have. If the influencers can curate their online lives as they do, we also have the power to curate them out of our line of sight if we find ourselves in self-hatred spirals from seeing their posts!

If that means unfollowing, muting, or hiding people, so be it. Comparison is the thief of joy. We already receive enough of the â€œnot good enoughâ€ messaging. Youâ€™re allowed to not engage on social media with stuff that you donâ€™t want to see, for any reason, period end.

OP, I am sorry youâ€™re caught in this loop of anxiety/insecurity. It absolutely sucks to feel this way. I want you to know that youâ€™re amazing as you are. Wow so... to me, you sound like a totally reasonable person who knows their worth and isnâ€™t willing to settle for being treated like trash. Good for you for knowing what your boundaries are and enforcing them.

Things like poor communication, any kind of cheating, disrespect, a partner being controlling/overbearing (a very common abuse red flag), etc. are all extremely normal reasons to leave a relationship. If youâ€™re being treated badly and have tried to communicate about the other personâ€™s behavior, and they donâ€™t change, well... itâ€™s not your responsibility to make them a better person. Some people are going to be inconsiderate jerks, and itâ€™s not â€œpickyâ€ of you to refuse to do the emotional labor of being in a relationship with them.â€

Itâ€™s not like you have superficial â€œhigh standardsâ€ like â€œhe must be 6â€™2â€, drive a BMW, make 150k a year, have a dog, love the same sports teams I do...â€ etc. What youâ€™re asking for is basic, basic stuff: to be treated like a human being, for the other person to be mature and put in the same amount of effort you do, to contribute positively to the relationship.

You donâ€™t have to choose between a relationship and respect. You can have both. It just takes the right person. Donâ€™t settle until you find them.

One of the other commenters suggested hair oil and I second that- I also get dry ends on my hair and oil helps a lot! Coconut oil is great for this type of use and it smells super good- when your hair is wet after the shower, pat it dry with a towel (aggressive rubbing with a towel will rough up the strands so try to be gentle, I use a microfiber towel cause itâ€™s not as rough) and then put a little bit of coconut oil on the ends and anywhere that feels dry! Donâ€™t put any on the roots/close to your scalp, just like... finger comb it through the length of your hair. Then you can blow dry it or air dry it! It gives you a nice shine, a little bit goes a looooong way, you can buy it at pretty much any grocery store... pretty great all around. It feels soft and smells amazing!

Girl this is a golden opportunity for you. I have had a similar experience with getting out of a long term relationship in which my partner acted like I didnâ€™t exist/everything about me was wrong and it was the best thing that ever happened to me. Hereâ€™s my survival tips: 
- It may sound cliche but â€œdate yourself.â€ Treat yourself special. Everything you do, do it for yourself. Cherish your damn self! Now is the time to do that! Take as much time as you need to Do You without worrying about someone else.
- When youâ€™re ready for a partner, youâ€™ll know. Youâ€™ve spent 9 years prioritizing someone who wasnâ€™t prioritizing you, and those patterns of self-giving can be well worn and hard to break, so it seems easy to be in the â€œgotta find a relationshipâ€ mindset. I did the same thing. But until youâ€™ve healed from this one, anything else is gonna be a non-starter.
- Do some journaling, soul-searching, or whatever to get clear on what you want out of future relationships and what kind of partner you want. What are the qualities that person would ideally have? What kind of boundaries will you have around dating, relationships, your own autonomy? What are your values?
- I donâ€™t know a single person who gets  a full Brazilian wax so screw that noise. All joking aside, you own your body and it isnâ€™t your job to try to keep up with what the culture teaches (shallow, uninformed) men to expect from women. Make your own decisions about hair removal, personal style, whatever. You do not need to cater to some Male Gaze Fantasy.
- Accept nothing less than being treated like a person, and look at men the same way: theyâ€™re just people. Youâ€™re a person; theyâ€™re people. 
- You GOT this and I am rooting for you. I wish you all the good things!

My parents gaslit the heck outta me about â€œwho I am.â€ They would say things like:

â€œYouâ€™re fiercely competitive!â€
â€œYouâ€™re not afraid to BE YOURSELF!â€
â€œYou know who you are, you donâ€™t need to cling to fads or trends to find out!â€

I was ten thousand percent not competitive, and â€œwho I wasâ€ was constructed entirely to please them, so I wouldnâ€™t get shamed, hit, or yelled at.

â€œWho I amâ€ is introverted, sensitive, and creative. Whenever I tried to express those things, I was mocked, or told I was â€œnever going to be anybody.â€ Anytime I tried to spend any time alone, they made fun of me. â€œHAHAHAH are you going to go BROOD IN YOUR ROOM like a MOOOOODY TEEEEEEN?!â€ 
Anytime I wanted to do things a normal teenager would do (hang out and chat on the phone with friends after I did my homework instead of training for competitive endurance sports for hours a day), I was mocked. â€œWhat would you be doing if you quit swim team? Sitting around at home on the phone with BOYS?â€

I didnâ€™t know who I was for so long and I wish I would have had the chance to be me for the first 20 years of my life instead of being them. Imagine how much ass we all could kick at being ourselves and how actualized we could be if weâ€™d been allowed to earlier in our lives.

No... the gaslighting part is telling someone to shut up and immediately quit feeling bad. Itâ€™s like â€œwell * I * think youâ€™re pretty so quit feeling sorry for yourself because Iâ€™m right and youâ€™re wrong!â€ It just makes you feel crazy and broken! 

Also like I said, feelings are NOT facts. But that doesnâ€™t make them any less real for the person experiencing them. They donâ€™t have to be factually true to be valid. There is a difference between correct and real.
Someone telling me Iâ€™m wrong isnâ€™t gonna help me feel any better in moments of distress. There is a difference between telling someone â€œhey like, those are very real irrational feelings, letâ€™s acknowledge themâ€ and â€œwell Iâ€™m gonna argue you down to prove youâ€™re wrong and once you realize youâ€™re wrong you wonâ€™t feel bad anymore.â€

Youâ€™re right- people with BDD donâ€™t see themselves accurately. I know this to be factually true, yet I still see myself the way I see myself. Knowing logically that my perception is inaccurate doesnâ€™t change it or correct it. I still see what I see and feel what I feel, and I know itâ€™s disordered thinking; but thatâ€™s how I see myself. Know what I mean? Telling me Iâ€™m wrong to feel this stuff just makes me feel crazy and stupid. It has to be OK to feel our feelings as they are without judging them. Thatâ€™s where healing begins.

Holy lord is this a revelation for me. Thank you for posting this. Sometimes I feel like my childhood trauma wasnâ€™t real. This really puts it in perspective.

It means:

- Listening with compassion 
- Not gaslighting (â€œshut up youâ€™re so prettyâ€ or â€œyouâ€™re crazy and this is all in your headâ€ or â€œjust stop comparing yourself to other peopleâ€ or â€œI donâ€™t see why youâ€™re so hung up on thisâ€)
- Acknowledging that feelings are not facts but theyâ€™re valid anyway and should be explored
- Not taking it personally when I criticize myself (â€œif youâ€™re a stumpy misshapen troll girl than what am I?â€)
- Not giving advice or implying itâ€™s my fault (â€œwell why donâ€™t you try waist training? My friend does itâ€ or â€œwell you could try to lose some weight, you do eat a lot of bagelsâ€)

Just kind of being like... yup, you feel these things, your feelings are valid, I know youâ€™re in pain right now, Iâ€™m here for you to talk through it until youâ€™re done with the racing thoughts. That type of support.

Iâ€™m a bioinformatics IT data analyst Monday through Friday 9-5 and musician/photographer the rest of the time, and I have a lot of feelings about this. 

Iâ€™ve worked some jobs in this field that I thought were stifling, and some that werenâ€™t. The difference between them, for me, was the level of autonomy I had, and the expectations of the workplace. 

When I had a high degree of autonomy and could â€œleave work at workâ€ at the end of the day, I didnâ€™t feel stifled at all. I would go in, do my thing, then go home and make my art and let my hair down and it was fine.

When I was micromanaged, had little control over the flow of my day, and was expected to stay as long as it took to get everything done all the time (as if nothing could wait until the next day), thatâ€™s when I felt stifled. I felt like I couldnâ€™t have a band practice or show on a weeknight, EVER, because who knows what time I have to stay at work until? Iâ€™d go into the office in the morning and be like â€œI have no idea when Iâ€™ll be able to leave.â€ And when I had people over my shoulder dictating my every move, I was far too mentally and emotionally exhausted to create anything of value.

The long and the short of it is, Iâ€™ve been doing the tech job/creative life thing for a while; Iâ€™ve gotten used to the separation of the two. I would not want to rely on my art for income. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™d be able to take creative risks and be true to myself if I were selling my art on the free market. I would have to make commercial art for a commercial purpose. Itâ€™s freeing to not have to do that. As long as my job gives me money to live and make the most of my free time, Iâ€™m for it. When my job starts taking up more than its fair share of time and energy, thatâ€™s when it becomes unbalanced.

It really is! Sometimes all it takes is acknowledging it out loud. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s so great to have someone to bounce these things off of. I canâ€™t afford therapy right now cause I donâ€™t have insurance, but I look forward to the day when I can go back and address this stuff!

Yeah that makes sense. I also wouldnâ€™t post my phone number on the internet! But yeah itâ€™s like, people who donâ€™t have BDD donâ€™t understand how to speak to someone who does without invalidating us, making us feel crazy, or scoffing at us for being irrational. Thatâ€™s why I canâ€™t talk to anyone close to me about it- none of them get it on this level and can respond appropriately!

â€œNo one wakes up suicidal and traumatized.â€ DANG. That hit me so hard because itâ€™s so true. Iâ€™m sorry youâ€™re going through this garbage too. It takes up so much mental and emotional space we could both be using for better things. I extend the offer to you as well: PM me if you feel triggered and trapped in these feelings.

1. Playing music

I havenâ€™t actually quit a job without something else already lined up, but I had a job that was so awful that I gave myself a quitting deadline (my birthday that year) if I hadnâ€™t moved on by then. Luckily I found something before my birthday and was able to get out of that clusterheck.

Iâ€™ve moved on from multiple jobs that were toxic environments. A lot of workplaces are garbage, emotionally abusive hellholes. Having had this experience, I advise you to get the hell out of that place as soon as you can. Post your resume on a few sites, update your LinkedIn, send out applications on your lunch break.

Your family isnâ€™t you. Theyâ€™re not the ones experiencing this stress and spending every day unhappy and distraught. They donâ€™t feel how bad this is acutely every day like you do. They do not know best. You know you and itâ€™s your life. Your time is precious and finite. Do not waste it in misery.

A couple years ago I did a DBT-based partial hospitalization program and they taught us all sorts of stuff for mindfulness and emotion regulation. These are the ones I found most helpful:
1. Carry an essential oil with you that has a calming scent- a lot of people like lavender or peppermint.
2. If you feel like youâ€™re about to panic, splash your face with cold water (look up dive response and anxiety to learn more).
3. Use the 5 Senses- name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can hear, 3 things you can feel, 2 things you can smell, 1 thing you can taste. This is a grounding exercise that brings you back to the present moment and the world around you.
4. Progressive muscle relaxation - look this up too! It works for me when Iâ€™m awake in the night with anxiety and I canâ€™t get back to sleep.
5. Like the previous commenter said, box breathing is great!
I highly recommend looking into some DBT worksheets. There are tons of free ones on the Internet. I did my partial program over a year ago and I still pull out those DBT sheets when Iâ€™m feeling like Iâ€™m in a bad place. I wish you the best- this is a tough and stressful time for you for sure but I believe you can get through it!

This has happened twice in my life:
The first one: I had a friend in high school who I had sort of a silent falling out with. She was a good friend for a while but then things got weird and tense. I had a strange, emotionally abusive upbringing and complex trauma and I was certainly not aware of it or good at dealing with it as a teen, so that was certainly a factor. She transferred schools when we were like 15 and we didnâ€™t speak for a couple years. Then freshman year of college she got back in touch and we have been tight ever since. Iâ€™m so happy that happened and our friendship is rock solid.
The second one: my ex-roommate and ex-bandmate was a great friend for a while but she had a lot of issues. Very little compassion/empathy, horrible at feelings in general, did a lot of fat shaming and body shaming, was manipulative and mean and cruel and hypocritical. I decided I didnâ€™t want to work with her creatively anymore cause it was causing me a great deal of stress, and when that happened she saw no use in being friends with me. We havenâ€™t spoken in years. A mutual friend of ours had something pretty horrible happen in his life recently and apparently she heard about it and reached out to me on FB Messenger, which I never check. I came across the message weeks after it was sent and decided to just not click it. I donâ€™t want to open the door to having a toxic person like that in my life.
Sometimes itâ€™s pretty immediate. Like within an hour or so. Sometimes itâ€™s immediate and then the symptoms continue for an additional 12-ish hours after I eat the trigger food.
Heck yes- thank you! This is a great resource!

I understand this unfairness in attitude so deeply- I was in a long term relationship through my 20s, and during that time, there was so much shade thrown at us about not being married. My exâ€™s mother even said (more like drunkenly slurred) to me once, â€œyouâ€™re not a wife, youâ€™re just a GIIIIRLFRIEEEEENDâ€ and told him on the phone â€œif you donâ€™t marry her, sheâ€™s going to leave you.â€ No one in our families ever knew how to treat us- they had this hang up that we werenâ€™t married so there was this bizarre distance, but we had been together too long to not treat each other like a member of the family, so it was basically awkward and weird for 9 years or so. (Anyway he ended up being a serial cheater and liar after all so Iâ€™m retroactively glad we didnâ€™t get married cause that would have made it a lot worse.) But I always felt that sting of â€œno one respects or understands our relationship because we didnâ€™t sign a piece of paper.â€ I guess I stand on the side of â€œas long as both people in the relationship are happy and living the way they want to live, screw the haters.â€ But it isnâ€™t always easy- family and society can be very influential.

At least where Iâ€™m from, itâ€™s the law to allow employees to take a 30 minute lunch break if your workday is 8 hours. If they tell you youâ€™re not allowed to take a lunch break, thatâ€™s a labor law violation. Not sure if thatâ€™s the case where you are, but it may be a good idea to look into the labor laws regarding breaks. 
I would casually bring this up in conversation with your direct manager- during onboarding when they get you situated, you can casually ask â€œhey whatâ€™s normal for this team in terms of start time/what time do people usually head out for the day?â€ Then your manager can tell you what the norm is for others in the group. Odds are, there will be some variation/flexibility/autonomy in start/end times. 
Thatâ€™s definitely a more friendly conversation than â€œI will be leaving at the stroke of 5 each day and not a minute later.â€ 
Itâ€™s really about the company culture (and industry culture more broadly) - but there is no harm in asking what the expectations are in a friendly, exploratory way. Iâ€™ve started asking those types of questions in interviews and hiring managers have been very receptive to answering them. The employee and the company have to be a good fit for each other and thatâ€™s one way to find out!
